intro: Isocarpha atriplicifolia var. atriplicifolia, commonly known as the common isocarpha, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single bloom. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. It has narrow, linear leaves arranged in a basal rosette and produces small, yellowish flowers in clusters. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and wildlife.
